Suspect named in shooting of trooper during traffic stop in HyannisAuthorities on Tuesday identified the suspect in last week’s shooting of State Police Trooper John Lennon during a traffic stop in Hyannis as a 35-year-old man with ties to Florida and the West Coast, whom officials said remains at large and should be considered armed and dangerous.

A beautiful resistance | JENEÉ OSTERHELDTIf you’re willing to see, the walls have something to say In Worcester, Che Anderson speaks the language of establishment and the streets. As deputy cultural development officer and founding director of the POW! WOW! Worcester mural festival, Anderson understands cans of spray paint are a revolution of representation. He, along with colleagues Erin Williams, Gloria Hall, and Tina Zlody, are among the many who’ve helped transform Worcester into a city of art.

Behind the shieldFor Boston police officers accused of crimes, legal troubles tend to just melt awayBoston police officers accused of crimes over the last decade have encountered a kinder, gentler justice system than the one civilians must navigate — a system where justice takes a back seat to protecting officers.

I knew getting prostate cancer at 48 would change me. I had no idea how muchFor the past year, Mark Shanahan has been working on Mr. 80 Percent, a six-episode podcast miniseries about his experience with prostate cancer. It’s a deeply personal, sometimes harrowing, often funny story about a disease that affects millions of men. The heroes are his doctors and family, who put up with some appalling behavior. You’ll hear from both.

The virus’s taleTrack the coronavirus pandemic in Massachusetts to its roots and you find a story driven by heroics, ingenuity, error, pain, and a hard question: How could a state famous for health care excellence have suffered such a vast loss of human life?

Last Words: Is death the great equalizer?Quite the contrary, a Spotlight investigation shows. Death exposes in high relief the layers of inequities, in race and income, care and opportunity, that shape life down to its final hours. It is a truth the pandemic has only underscored — one hard to see, because it is so much easier to look away.

Death exposes in high relief the layers of inequities, in race and income, care and opportunity, that shape life down to its final hours. It is a truth the pandemic has only underscored — one hard to see, because it is so much easier to look away.

Dow closes above 30,000 points for first time ever on vaccine hopes, Biden transitionThe Dow rose 454 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 30,046. The S&P 500 index, which has a far greater impact on 401(k) accounts than the Dow does, rose 1.6 percent.

Man, 71, arrested for allegedly spitting at women in Ashburnham and telling them he has COVID-19Authorities have charged a 71-year-old man with spitting at two women on Nov. 15 on an Ashburnham hiking trail and telling them he has COVID-19 after earlier chiding the pair for not wearing masks, according to law enforcement officials.

Suspect named in shooting of trooper during traffic stop in HyannisAuthorities on Tuesday identified the suspect in last week’s shooting of State Police Trooper John Lennon during a traffic stop in Hyannis as a 35-year-old man with ties to Florida and the West Coast, whom officials said remains at large and should be considered armed and dangerous.
Harvard gets its first Black, elected student body presidentA 20-year-old from Mississippi has become the first Black, elected student body president at Harvard University.

Perhaps more than ever, online shopping is changing the seasonal workforce in 2020 Seasonal gigs at big-box stores now increasingly involve packing orders for pick-ups or shipping them to customer’s homes, while transportation, logistics, and warehousing jobs are anticipated to triple this year as consumers conquer their gift lists online.

A beautiful resistance | JENEÉ OSTERHELDTIf you’re willing to see, the walls have something to say In Worcester, Che Anderson speaks the language of establishment and the streets. As deputy cultural development officer and founding director of the POW! WOW! Worcester mural festival, Anderson understands cans of spray paint are a revolution of representation. He, along with colleagues Erin Williams, Gloria Hall, and Tina Zlody, are among the many who’ve helped transform Worcester into a city of art.

Here’s the throwback story behind Revere’s infomercial-style video for COVID-19 testingCity officials are relying on a more lighthearted method of boosting public awareness: by reprising the role of a satirical character from a popular YouTube video that’s nearly a decade old.

Behind the shieldFor Boston police officers accused of crimes, legal troubles tend to just melt awayBoston police officers accused of crimes over the last decade have encountered a kinder, gentler justice system than the one civilians must navigate — a system where justice takes a back seat to protecting officers.

First-of-its-kind study finds ‘stunning’ earnings gains for immigrants who learn EnglishUnemployed residents with prior US work experience who enrolled in an employment-focused English course boosted their earnings by an average of more than $7,100 annually, compared with unemployed non-English speakers.

I knew getting prostate cancer at 48 would change me. I had no idea how muchFor the past year, Mark Shanahan has been working on Mr. 80 Percent, a six-episode podcast miniseries about his experience with prostate cancer. It’s a deeply personal, sometimes harrowing, often funny story about a disease that affects millions of men. The heroes are his doctors and family, who put up with some appalling behavior. You’ll hear from both.
